JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVII, NO. 9.

BALTIMORE, MD.,.DECEMBER 2, 1912.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

TO GO TO WESTERN MARYLAND

MASS-MEETING HELD

FRESHMEN, 7.; SOPHOMORES, 0

J. H. U. GOES DOWN BEFORE V. M. I.

Musical Clubs Will Forsake Their Happy
Hunting Ground on Eastern Shore.
Will Go West for the Holidays.

Students Assemble to Hear Article in
Monday's "Evening Sun" Criticized
By Football Management.

Annual Struggle on the Gridiron For
Class Supremacy—Contest Exciting
From Start to Finish.

The Varsity Players Put Up a Snappy
Game in the Final Contest
of the Season.
•

Although no definite plans have
been formed, it is understood that
the Musical Clubs will go to Western Maryland this year, instead of
the Eastern Shore, where they have
spent the Christmas holidays since
time immemorial.
Concerts were given last year in
Chestertown, Easton and Salisbury.
At none of the towns were there
good audiences and, in consequence,
the exchequer was so low, that most
of the men had to dip down in their
pockets to pay railroad fares. All
of this loss was made up by the Baltimore concerts, but this meant less
money for the Hullaboloos, which
are considerably in need of such
support. Besides this, the transportation facilities of the Eastern
Shore are such as to require long
railroad trips to cover relatively
short distances. With the additional
idea that "we have worn out our
welcome," it seems eminently desirable to give this section of the
State time to recover.
Frederick, Hagerstown and Cumberland seem suitable places to give
concerts, though the question of
making railroad connections remains to be considered. With
Christmas coming on Wednesday,
the Clubs will probably leave the
next day and give concerts on
Thursday, Friday and Saturday
nights. -Jack Fulton, who has taken
over the work of training the Glee
Club and arranging the trips, has not
announced anything definite as yet.
Following the football mass-meeting, last Wednesday, a very successful rehearsal of the Glee Club was
held. It was decided to have rehearsals for the tenors on Mondays
at one o'clock, and for the bassos on
Wednesdays, at the same hour. A
gen&al rehearsal will take place on
Fridays. Fulton has requested any
one knowing persons in Frederick,
Hagerstown or Cumberland to giyie
his name to him in order.to increase
the list of patrons.

On Wednesaay last, a mass-meeting of the entire student body was
held in Hopkins Hall to bring to
light the facts in regard to an article
in Monday's Evening Sun, which
blamed the lack of success of the
football team on lack of funds, fraternity rivalry and general mismanagement, and which stated that
"H's" would not be awarded this
year. The article was signed by
one "A. E. H."
Freddie Lee opened the meeting
and called on Harry Burgan. The
graduate manager first read the
article above mentioned, and then
a letter which stated the true facts
addressed to the sporting editor of
the Evening Sui. and signed by
everybody in any way concerned.
This letter absolutely denied that
Coach Harlan had asked for funds
and "had been turned down cold,"
denied that any friction existed between Manager Ellicott and Graduate Manager Burgan, and denied
that G. Pitts Raleigh had told some
members of the squad that their
"H's" would be withheld.
Assistant Coach Dick McCabe
then spoke, praising the spirit of the
squad and particularly of the scrubs,
and ending with an urgent appeal
for backing from the side lines in
the last game of the season, as the
team had worked for and deserved
it.
Coach Fulton further emphasized
the falsity of the article in the Sun,
adding that as large a squad had
been on the field every day as he
had ever seen in previous years.
Manager Ellicott denied that
there was the least friction in the
management, and added that if there
were any, it would certainly be
known and much talked of at the
University.
Mr. C. L. Getz, the Hopkins reporter of the Evening Suit, explained how the article got into the
paper, disclaiming any connection
with it, and saying that the sporting
editor had insisted on running it
without even showing it to him,
much against his advice and warning. He had since found that the
article had been written by a regular staff reporter of the paper.
A motion was then made by Mr.
Leland, and unanimously carried,
condemning the article in the Sun
and highly commending the team,
the scrubs and the entire management for their work this year.

The Freshmen defeated t h e
Sophomores 7 to o last Saturday in
the annual struggle for gridiron
supremacy between the two classes.
The game was exciting from start
to finish, for the result was in doubt
at all times.
The only score of the contest came
early in the second quarter, when
Captain George Penniman of the
Freshies carried the ball over the
line. The second year team was
never dangerously near the Freshman goal line, while the younger
players kept the ball in striking distance of their opponents' goal most
of the time.
Penniman was easily the star of
the game, being the chief groundgainer for the Freshman, and a
tower of strength in backing up the
line. Next to him, Woodward, at
right end, did the best work. He
followed the ball closely, and recovered three fumbles behind the
Sophomore line. Little Johnny
Knipp also played well, and ran
back kicks for good gains.
The particular star for the Sophs
was Troxell, who was the only man
to gain consistently against the
strong Freshman line. His work on
the defensive left nothing to be desired, as he was in almost every
play.
The game was notable for the lack
of open plays, which the Freshmen
did not risk, after they had the game
won, and which the Sophs could not
carry out on account of their line's
inability to hold long enough for
them to be gotten off.
The line-up:

Virginia Military Institute defeated Johns Hopkins- Thanksgiving Day on Homewood Field by the
score of 21 to o in the last game of
a season in which the. Black and
Blue has not won a contest.
The 'Varsity did not expect to
Win, but it put up a "Custer's Last
Rally" stand against the cadets,
making them fight for every gain.
As if in defiance of the impudent
criticism of the 'Varsity made in
last Monday's Evening Sun, the
Hopkins players put up one of the
most spirited and snappy games of
the season.
The contest early turned into a
kicking contest; and Virginia gained
on the exchanges, Fullback Moore
being a better punter than Bagley
of the Black and Blue. In justice
to Bagley, however, it must be
brought out that he did not go into
the contest expecting to be called
upon to punt after nearly every
other down. Captain Gillet was to
have been Hopkins' punter this season, and after he was removed from
the game it was too late to develop
another to take his place. Bagley
and George Penniman starred in the
backfield, and Vic Bridgman was
the best player on the line. Bridgman made some fine tackles and recovered several fumbled balls.
The Virginia players were older
and more experienced in the finer
points of the game. Captain Moore
and Kingman shown above the other
cadets, and this pair not only rolled
up all 21 points, but they were in
every play, both defensive and offensive. They have been playing for
_Virginia for three years. The elevens, however, were about even in
weight.
Virginia played a scrappy game,
hitting the line hard and tackling
almost with a vengeance. The interference for Moore on end runs
was good, but the backfield did not
attempt many plays through the
'Varsity line.
Hopkins rooters turned out with
a band and supported the team with
cheers and songs under the direction
of Butts Sutton until the last whistle
was blown. Both team and student
body closed the victoryless season
in a graceful and spirited manner.
Virginia did its scoring in the first,.
second and fourth quarters. La
Motte opened the game kicking to
Centre Patterson who advanced to
the Hopkins 60-yard line. An incomplete pass was followed by a
15-yard throw from Moore to
Lowery who went five yards more.

The Geology I Class is keeping up
its good work of "getting close to
nature." Last Wednesday the class
made a trip to Curtis Bay, where
ancient river terraces were studied
and many interesting facts explained. During the past few weeks
the class has made trips to Mt.
Washington, Bare Hills and Hawkins Point in order to study the
geology of the vicinity of Baltimore
at close range.

THE MADISON

GIVEN FREE REIN BY TAFT
Miss Julia Lathrop Tells of Work in
Her Bureau.

Declaring that President Taft had
given her a free rein in selecting
employees for the department, Miss
Julia Lathrop, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Department
of Commerce and Labor, addressed
a meeting of the Instructive Visiting Nurses' Association last week at
McCoy Hall on the work which she
had planned for the bureau.
The audience was large, including
a number of persons not actively
identified with the Association. Dr.
Joseph S. Ames, president of the organization, presided, and in hii
speech of introduction declared that
nurses must do much more than
merely nurse the sick, pointing out
to them that social service offered
many opportunities for aiding the
poor and needy.
In her report for the work of the
sixteenth year of the Association,
Miss Mary E. Lent, superintendent
of nurses, called attention to the
fact that 6,024 patients had been
treated in the year, requiring 46,467
visits. She said the Association had
co-operated with other agencies for
the amelioration of the condition of
the poor and that Christmas dinners,
toys and other articles had been
given 634 patients.
Dr. Ames, in presenting Miss La-

throp, said that her work in Chicago at the Hull House, under Miss
Jane Addams, had been such as to
make her the only woman in the
country fitted to perform the duties
of director of the Children's Bureau,
which President Taft organized last
April.
.

Federated Charities-

On last Tuesday at eight o'clock
the annual meeting of the Federated
Charities was held in McCoy Hall.
A fairly large audience was present
at the meeting. The president, General Lawrason Riggs, presided. The
general secretary of the Federation,
Dr. Magruder, gave an interesting
summary of the last year's work,
illustrating his remarks with wellselected lantern slides. Dr. Magruder traced the progress made by the
Federated Charities during the past
year, and gave hopes for great expectations in the future.
The next speaker was Mrs. John
M. Glenn, well known for her writings and social work. She read a
paper on "Volunteer Visitors,"
showing their good work in the
social line. The last speaker was
Dr. Richard C. Cabot, Superintendent of the Massachusetts General
Hospital in Boston. He spoke on
"Social Work in Hospitals," and
gave an interesting discourse on
social service as related to the medical profession.

The first smoker for the year 1912
and an important meeting of the
Johns Hopkins Alumni Association
for New York and New Jersey will
be held at the City Club of New
York, 55 West Forty-fourth street,
on Friday, December 6, at 8.30
P.M.
The,business to be transacted will
be a consideration of reports on the
following matters:
T. The proposed biographical calendar of all former students of the
University.
2. Proposed permanent quarters
for the Association.
3. Arrangements for the annual
dinner in January or February next,
to which the invited guests will be:
President Remsn of the University; R. Brent Keyser, president of
the Board of Trustees; the Hon.
James Bryce, former lecturer at the
University; the Hon. Woodrow
Wilson, former student and lecturer.
A Letter From Woodrow Wilson.
The following letter from President-elect Woodrow Wilson was received last Tuesday by C. Leland
Getz, vice-president of the Johns
Hopkins Woodrow Wilson Club:
MY DEAR MR. GETZ:
I want to give myself the pleasure,
not only of acknowledging your kind
letter of congratulation, but of expressing
in turn my appreciation of the active
and intelligent work you have done. A,
the leader of the party, I feel that I
owe you a direct personal expression of
sincere thanks.
Cordially yours,
WOODROW WILSON.

The day after election Mr. Getz
wrote Governor Wilson a letter congratulating him both personally and
on behalf of the members of the
Johns Hopkins Woodrow Wilson
Club.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 2, 1912
A Season of Reverses.

The foot-ball season is over. Hopkins has succeeded in losing nine
straight games, without winning
one. Such a record is truly a thing
of beauty, a rounded and symmetrical whole, which it would have been
a real pity for us to spoil by happening, even just once, to win a game.
But any danger of such a calamity is
now past; the season is over, the
anxiety is ended, and our perfect
record of defeats has come forth
saved. Post mortem examinations
of why we did not win are going
on with their usual animation in the
basement of McCoy Hall; and, of
course, everybody and everything,
from dea Fortuna and Coath Harlan down to the weather and the
schedule, is getting the blame.
Into such a post Dorton THE
NEws-LETTER does not propose to
enter here; but what it does want
to impress on everybody is that
"snap judgment" should not be
formed on an insufficient or distorted knowledge of the facts. An
example of such "snap judgment"
was the article which appeared in
last Monday's issue of the Evening
Sun. The impression which this
article was calculated to produce
was entirely erroneous and unfounded. Whatever faults may be laid at
the door of the football team, petty
personal jealousies and ungenerous
fraternity rivalries are not among
them. The team may not have
tackled well, may not have punted
well, may not have been able to
catch forward passes, may not have
acted as a unit on the field; but one
thing that can be said of it with
absolute certainty is that it was pervaded with a cordial and harmonious spirit of good fellowship. The
article in the Evening Sun displayed
a lamentable ignorance of actual

conditions, and it is to be hoped that
the reply published by Messrs. Burroughs, Stone, et al., in Wednesday's issue of the same paper successfully corrected any misconceptions which the former article might
have created.
Whatever may have been the
cause of Hopkins' unbroken series
of defeats this year—and it cannot
be denied that Hick had much to do
with them—we should not be pessimistic. This year, with a raw team
and a coach new to Hopkins conditions,, an unsuccessful season might
have been .expected. Next year it
looks as if matters will stand differently. Only two members of this
year's team—Captain Gillet, whose
injury prevented his playing during
the greater part of the season, and
the efficient Dollinger, who appeared
• in only two games—will be removed
by graduation. With a whole year's
experience behind it, our present
team ought to go into the field next
fall greatly improved. Now that
the technical department has been
opened, it may be predicted that
the freshman class will be unusually large and will afford considerable good football material. By insistence upon regular attendance at
practices, Coach Harlan has been
steadily improving the discipline of
the team, and, if he returns next
year, he will know the needs of Hopkins football as no coach in his first
year's residence can possibly know
them. All these things taken together ought to tell for a season
•which will be at least more successful than the past one has been.
we ought not to be discouraged. It is well for us to remember
at all times, but now in particular,
that the reputation of a college does
not, or at least should not, stand
on football. It is a splendid thing
for us to have a winning football
team: it is unfortunate that we have
had so unsuccessful a season, and it
is to be hoped that we shall retrieve
ourselves next year; but if we.
judge ourselves by football, we shall
come out at the small end of the
horn, indeed. St. John's is able to
beat Johns Hopkins at football • as
an institution of learning Johns
Hopkins takes its place in the class
with Harvard, Columbia and Cornell
—a class so far above St. John's
head that it may not even hope ever
to rise to it.

The Football Team.

November 29, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
I would like to express a few
words in regards towards the football team of the season just closed.
Of course, this season has been a
great disappointment to Hopkins
and her supporters in a great many
ways. But in other ways it has
proved a benefit in disguise. But
some disguises, like practical jokes,
may not always seem funny or
clever.
But on all college teams there
comes some year when graduation
ruins the teatn of the following
year. This was just our case. We
started out with two men who had
played on the team one year, two
who had played two years, and only
one who had played three years.
Even these men had not been regulars all their respective years of

playing. Later several more men
came out who had been subs. About
these men a team had to be built.
As our season started so late we had
to go ahead and play games before
the new and inexperienced men had
been fully drilled. Besides football
has to be born in —a player or else
learned, by experience. Unfortunately, knowledge of football did
not seem to have been born in many
of our crew.
But one of the ways in which we
were benefited was the opportunity
given the undergraduates to learn
at first hand. In a year or two the
team will be a wonder. I only hope
that this season will not influence
the future manager towards easing
up the schedule. I believe there is
no necessity for such action.
Also, I want to thank all the students for the way in which they
have backed us up this fall and particularly all who came out to practice and gave us the largest squad
that there ever has been there.
Thanking you, I am
Very sincerely,
GEORGE M. GILLET, JR.

He's a Bee.

To the Editor of the Co-Ed's Column:
I was very much amused at the
letters in the Co-eds' Column last
week. The•first letter was evidently
written by a fellow, not by a girl,
whether the second one was written
by a fair co-ed, or not. The writer
of the first letter is evidently a
freshman, or, if an upperclassman,
one who knows nothing about girls.
•Probably, he has made a specialty of
old maids; for in his letter he has
the supposed girl say that she wants
to walk up and down the halls arm
in arm with the fellows. Everybody knows that it is the old maid
not the fair maiden who is forced
to make such unblushing suggestions. They are forced like Diogenes ever to be on the look-out for
honest men. The young ,ladies
don't have to. Flowers don't have
to go in search of bees.
I wish to acknowledge from the
very start that I am a bee in search
of f- lowers, and will not pretend I
am a flower in search of bees. What
I am interested in is how to induce
flowers to turn their heads my way.
There was a fine suggestion in Life
the other day, which had been made
by a professor in the University of
Pennsylvania. He said that college students should be encouraged
to write love letters to help them in
their English literature courses. He
claimed that just as birds learn to
sing exquisitely from the practice
they have gotten in singing to their
mates, so college students would
learn to write beautifully if they
were encouraged to write to their
sweethearts. When I had read this I
threw down the Life on the Y. M.
C. A. table at which I had been
reading and went rushing up to Dr.
Greene's room to tell him that I
would be willing to write a love
letter to any girl he might select, if
he would excuse me from the lesson in the Prologue, which he had
assigned for Monday. But when
half way up the stairs, I recollected
that the blooming Pennsylvania professor had said that the letter should
be supervised before being sent to
their destination. I was willing to
let him select the girl I was to write
to, as I felt sure he must know a lot
of lovely ones, but I didn't know if
I would care to have him go oyer
the letters I had written. He might
make me put some Chaucer in them.
But, then, I thought, parts of Chaucer are darn good stuff to put in a
love letter. The arguments in favor
of going to Dr. Greene, and those
for not going being equally balanced,
I decided to write to you to ask \ 11
what I should do.
Anxiously awaiting a reply, I reA BOLD SOPHOMORE.

Sporting Editor The Evening. Sun:
Dear Sir—An article appearing in The
Evening Sun of Monday, November 25,
relating to football affairs at Hopkins,
is full of errors injurious to the institution and to individuals, and we ask
the courtesy of a place on your page for
this letter, signed by all the men especially interested in the article.

The- following categorical denials of
statements or intimations in said article
are made without fear of contradiction:
In headlines and in the body of the
story an assertion appears that the "H"
will not be,given to the players this
year, Bridgenan and La Motte especially being. mentioned. The letters are
awarded by the General Athletic Association, which has not yet met for this
purpose. There has been no movement
to prevent the usual awarding of the
"H"s, and certainly no reason for stating that they will not be awarded;- nor
did Mr. Raleigh, at any time, so state
to any member of the team.
Coach Harlan is represented as being
ready to "throw up the sponge" on many
occasions. This is untrue, and is a gross
injustice to the loyalty and sportsmanship of a coach who has been formally
notified that his work is highly satisfactory.
The entire description of the alleged
action of G. Pitts Raleigh is false, both
as to time, place and substance of his
supposed interviews with players.
The intimation that fraternity rivalries
are responsible for the "smash-up of the
team," not only has no foundation in
fact, but lacks even the appearance of
truth. As evidence of this, Raleigh,
Bridgeman and La Motte, represented as
being at odds, are all members of the
same fraternity.
The statement that funds for equipment were lacking, and that Coach Harlan's requests for apparatus were "turned
down cold," are totally untrue. .
The, utterly inaccurate nature of the.
article is seen in the attempt to fasten
criticism for the playing schedule on
Harry Burgan. Mr. Burgan had absolutely no connection with the football
management until many months after
the schedule was fixed.
,The article concludes with the intimation that while bad luck has played some
part in the defeats of the team, that dissensions, mismanagements and petty politics are really at fault. We do not
care to hide behind "hard luck." There
are a number of definite causes why
games were lost, chief of which is the
scarcity and inexperience of'football material. But losing games does not necessarily mean a totally disastrous season.
. One of the best achievements of the
year has been the solidarity and faithfulness of the football squad as a whole,
and the hearty support of the student
body as evidenced upon such occasions
as the St. John's game.
We trust that your usual fairminded
attitude toward Hopkins athletics will
secure this' letter a prominent place in
your columns.
HORACE BURROUGHS,

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVII, NO. 9.

BALTIMORE, MD.,.DECEMBER 2, 1912.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

TO GO TO WESTERN MARYLAND

MASS-MEETING HELD

FRESHMEN, 7.; SOPHOMORES, 0

J. H. U. GOES DOWN BEFORE V. M. I.

Musical Clubs Will Forsake Their Happy
Hunting Ground on Eastern Shore.
Will Go West for the Holidays.

Students Assemble to Hear Article in
Monday's "Evening Sun" Criticized
By Football Management.

Annual Struggle on the Gridiron For
Class Supremacy—Contest Exciting
From Start to Finish.

The Varsity Players Put Up a Snappy
Game in the Final Contest
of the Season.
•

Although no definite plans have
been formed, it is understood that
the Musical Clubs will go to Western Maryland this year, instead of
the Eastern Shore, where they have
spent the Christmas holidays since
time immemorial.
Concerts were given last year in
Chestertown, Easton and Salisbury.
At none of the towns were there
good audiences and, in consequence,
the exchequer was so low, that most
of the men had to dip down in their
pockets to pay railroad fares. All
of this loss was made up by the Baltimore concerts, but this meant less
money for the Hullaboloos, which
are considerably in need of such
support. Besides this, the transportation facilities of the Eastern
Shore are such as to require long
railroad trips to cover relatively
short distances. With the additional
idea that "we have worn out our
welcome," it seems eminently desirable to give this section of the
State time to recover.
Frederick, Hagerstown and Cumberland seem suitable places to give
concerts, though the question of
making railroad connections remains to be considered. With
Christmas coming on Wednesday,
the Clubs will probably leave the
next day and give concerts on
Thursday, Friday and Saturday
nights. -Jack Fulton, who has taken
over the work of training the Glee
Club and arranging the trips, has not
announced anything definite as yet.
Following the football mass-meeting, last Wednesday, a very successful rehearsal of the Glee Club was
held. It was decided to have rehearsals for the tenors on Mondays
at one o'clock, and for the bassos on
Wednesdays, at the same hour. A
gen&al rehearsal will take place on
Fridays. Fulton has requested any
one knowing persons in Frederick,
Hagerstown or Cumberland to giyie
his name to him in order.to increase
the list of patrons.

On Wednesaay last, a mass-meeting of the entire student body was
held in Hopkins Hall to bring to
light the facts in regard to an article
in Monday's Evening Sun, which
blamed the lack of success of the
football team on lack of funds, fraternity rivalry and general mismanagement, and which stated that
"H's" would not be awarded this
year. The article was signed by
one "A. E. H."
Freddie Lee opened the meeting
and called on Harry Burgan. The
graduate manager first read the
article above mentioned, and then
a letter which stated the true facts
addressed to the sporting editor of
the Evening Sui. and signed by
everybody in any way concerned.
This letter absolutely denied that
Coach Harlan had asked for funds
and "had been turned down cold,"
denied that any friction existed between Manager Ellicott and Graduate Manager Burgan, and denied
that G. Pitts Raleigh had told some
members of the squad that their
"H's" would be withheld.
Assistant Coach Dick McCabe
then spoke, praising the spirit of the
squad and particularly of the scrubs,
and ending with an urgent appeal
for backing from the side lines in
the last game of the season, as the
team had worked for and deserved
it.
Coach Fulton further emphasized
the falsity of the article in the Sun,
adding that as large a squad had
been on the field every day as he
had ever seen in previous years.
Manager Ellicott denied that
there was the least friction in the
management, and added that if there
were any, it would certainly be
known and much talked of at the
University.
Mr. C. L. Getz, the Hopkins reporter of the Evening Suit, explained how the article got into the
paper, disclaiming any connection
with it, and saying that the sporting
editor had insisted on running it
without even showing it to him,
much against his advice and warning. He had since found that the
article had been written by a regular staff reporter of the paper.
A motion was then made by Mr.
Leland, and unanimously carried,
condemning the article in the Sun
and highly commending the team,
the scrubs and the entire management for their work this year.

The Freshmen defeated t h e
Sophomores 7 to o last Saturday in
the annual struggle for gridiron
supremacy between the two classes.
The game was exciting from start
to finish, for the result was in doubt
at all times.
The only score of the contest came
early in the second quarter, when
Captain George Penniman of the
Freshies carried the ball over the
line. The second year team was
never dangerously near the Freshman goal line, while the younger
players kept the ball in striking distance of their opponents' goal most
of the time.
Penniman was easily the star of
the game, being the chief groundgainer for the Freshman, and a
tower of strength in backing up the
line. Next to him, Woodward, at
right end, did the best work. He
followed the ball closely, and recovered three fumbles behind the
Sophomore line. Little Johnny
Knipp also played well, and ran
back kicks for good gains.
The particular star for the Sophs
was Troxell, who was the only man
to gain consistently against the
strong Freshman line. His work on
the defensive left nothing to be desired, as he was in almost every
play.
The game was notable for the lack
of open plays, which the Freshmen
did not risk, after they had the game
won, and which the Sophs could not
carry out on account of their line's
inability to hold long enough for
them to be gotten off.
The line-up:

Virginia Military Institute defeated Johns Hopkins- Thanksgiving Day on Homewood Field by the
score of 21 to o in the last game of
a season in which the. Black and
Blue has not won a contest.
The 'Varsity did not expect to
Win, but it put up a "Custer's Last
Rally" stand against the cadets,
making them fight for every gain.
As if in defiance of the impudent
criticism of the 'Varsity made in
last Monday's Evening Sun, the
Hopkins players put up one of the
most spirited and snappy games of
the season.
The contest early turned into a
kicking contest; and Virginia gained
on the exchanges, Fullback Moore
being a better punter than Bagley
of the Black and Blue. In justice
to Bagley, however, it must be
brought out that he did not go into
the contest expecting to be called
upon to punt after nearly every
other down. Captain Gillet was to
have been Hopkins' punter this season, and after he was removed from
the game it was too late to develop
another to take his place. Bagley
and George Penniman starred in the
backfield, and Vic Bridgman was
the best player on the line. Bridgman made some fine tackles and recovered several fumbled balls.
The Virginia players were older
and more experienced in the finer
points of the game. Captain Moore
and Kingman shown above the other
cadets, and this pair not only rolled
up all 21 points, but they were in
every play, both defensive and offensive. They have been playing for
_Virginia for three years. The elevens, however, were about even in
weight.
Virginia played a scrappy game,
hitting the line hard and tackling
almost with a vengeance. The interference for Moore on end runs
was good, but the backfield did not
attempt many plays through the
'Varsity line.
Hopkins rooters turned out with
a band and supported the team with
cheers and songs under the direction
of Butts Sutton until the last whistle
was blown. Both team and student
body closed the victoryless season
in a graceful and spirited manner.
Virginia did its scoring in the first,.
second and fourth quarters. La
Motte opened the game kicking to
Centre Patterson who advanced to
the Hopkins 60-yard line. An incomplete pass was followed by a
15-yard throw from Moore to
Lowery who went five yards more.

The Geology I Class is keeping up
its good work of "getting close to
nature." Last Wednesday the class
made a trip to Curtis Bay, where
ancient river terraces were studied
and many interesting facts explained. During the past few weeks
the class has made trips to Mt.
Washington, Bare Hills and Hawkins Point in order to study the
geology of the vicinity of Baltimore
at close range.

THE MADISON

GIVEN FREE REIN BY TAFT
Miss Julia Lathrop Tells of Work in
Her Bureau.

Declaring that President Taft had
given her a free rein in selecting
employees for the department, Miss
Julia Lathrop, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Department
of Commerce and Labor, addressed
a meeting of the Instructive Visiting Nurses' Association last week at
McCoy Hall on the work which she
had planned for the bureau.
The audience was large, including
a number of persons not actively
identified with the Association. Dr.
Joseph S. Ames, president of the organization, presided, and in hii
speech of introduction declared that
nurses must do much more than
merely nurse the sick, pointing out
to them that social service offered
many opportunities for aiding the
poor and needy.
In her report for the work of the
sixteenth year of the Association,
Miss Mary E. Lent, superintendent
of nurses, called attention to the
fact that 6,024 patients had been
treated in the year, requiring 46,467
visits. She said the Association had
co-operated with other agencies for
the amelioration of the condition of
the poor and that Christmas dinners,
toys and other articles had been
given 634 patients.
Dr. Ames, in presenting Miss La-

throp, said that her work in Chicago at the Hull House, under Miss
Jane Addams, had been such as to
make her the only woman in the
country fitted to perform the duties
of director of the Children's Bureau,
which President Taft organized last
April.
.

Federated Charities-

On last Tuesday at eight o'clock
the annual meeting of the Federated
Charities was held in McCoy Hall.
A fairly large audience was present
at the meeting. The president, General Lawrason Riggs, presided. The
general secretary of the Federation,
Dr. Magruder, gave an interesting
summary of the last year's work,
illustrating his remarks with wellselected lantern slides. Dr. Magruder traced the progress made by the
Federated Charities during the past
year, and gave hopes for great expectations in the future.
The next speaker was Mrs. John
M. Glenn, well known for her writings and social work. She read a
paper on "Volunteer Visitors,"
showing their good work in the
social line. The last speaker was
Dr. Richard C. Cabot, Superintendent of the Massachusetts General
Hospital in Boston. He spoke on
"Social Work in Hospitals," and
gave an interesting discourse on
social service as related to the medical profession.

A Letter From Woodrow Wilson.
The following letter from President-elect Woodrow Wilson was received last Tuesday by C. Leland
Getz, vice-president of the Johns
Hopkins Woodrow Wilson Club:
MY DEAR MR. GETZ:
I want to give myself the pleasure,
not only of acknowledging your kind
letter of congratulation, but of expressing
in turn my appreciation of the active
and intelligent work you have done. A,
the leader of the party, I feel that I
owe you a direct personal expression of
sincere thanks.
Cordially yours,
WOODROW WILSON.

The day after election Mr. Getz
wrote Governor Wilson a letter congratulating him both personally and
on behalf of the members of the
Johns Hopkins Woodrow Wilson
Club.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 2, 1912
A Season of Reverses.

The foot-ball season is over. Hopkins has succeeded in losing nine
straight games, without winning
one. Such a record is truly a thing
of beauty, a rounded and symmetrical whole, which it would have been
a real pity for us to spoil by happening, even just once, to win a game.
But any danger of such a calamity is
now past; the season is over, the
anxiety is ended, and our perfect
record of defeats has come forth
saved. Post mortem examinations
of why we did not win are going
on with their usual animation in the
basement of McCoy Hall; and, of
course, everybody and everything,
from dea Fortuna and Coath Harlan down to the weather and the
schedule, is getting the blame.
Into such a post Dorton THE
NEws-LETTER does not propose to
enter here; but what it does want
to impress on everybody is that
"snap judgment" should not be
formed on an insufficient or distorted knowledge of the facts. An
example of such "snap judgment"
was the article which appeared in
last Monday's issue of the Evening
Sun. The impression which this
article was calculated to produce
was entirely erroneous and unfounded. Whatever faults may be laid at
the door of the football team, petty
personal jealousies and ungenerous
fraternity rivalries are not among
them. The team may not have
tackled well, may not have punted
well, may not have been able to
catch forward passes, may not have
acted as a unit on the field; but one
thing that can be said of it with
absolute certainty is that it was pervaded with a cordial and harmonious spirit of good fellowship. The
article in the Evening Sun displayed
a lamentable ignorance of actual

conditions, and it is to be hoped that
the reply published by Messrs. Burroughs, Stone, et al., in Wednesday's issue of the same paper successfully corrected any misconceptions which the former article might
have created.
Whatever may have been the
cause of Hopkins' unbroken series
of defeats this year—and it cannot
be denied that Hick had much to do
with them—we should not be pessimistic. This year, with a raw team
and a coach new to Hopkins conditions,, an unsuccessful season might
have been .expected. Next year it
looks as if matters will stand differently. Only two members of this
year's team—Captain Gillet, whose
injury prevented his playing during
the greater part of the season, and
the efficient Dollinger, who appeared
• in only two games—will be removed
by graduation. With a whole year's
experience behind it, our present
team ought to go into the field next
fall greatly improved. Now that
the technical department has been
opened, it may be predicted that
the freshman class will be unusually large and will afford considerable good football material. By insistence upon regular attendance at
practices, Coach Harlan has been
steadily improving the discipline of
the team, and, if he returns next
year, he will know the needs of Hopkins football as no coach in his first
year's residence can possibly know
them. All these things taken together ought to tell for a season
•which will be at least more successful than the past one has been.
we ought not to be discouraged. It is well for us to remember
at all times, but now in particular,
that the reputation of a college does
not, or at least should not, stand
on football. It is a splendid thing
for us to have a winning football
team: it is unfortunate that we have
had so unsuccessful a season, and it
is to be hoped that we shall retrieve
ourselves next year; but if we.
judge ourselves by football, we shall
come out at the small end of the
horn, indeed. St. John's is able to
beat Johns Hopkins at football • as
an institution of learning Johns
Hopkins takes its place in the class
with Harvard, Columbia and Cornell
—a class so far above St. John's
head that it may not even hope ever
to rise to it.

The Football Team.

November 29, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
I would like to express a few
words in regards towards the football team of the season just closed.
Of course, this season has been a
great disappointment to Hopkins
and her supporters in a great many
ways. But in other ways it has
proved a benefit in disguise. But
some disguises, like practical jokes,
may not always seem funny or
clever.
But on all college teams there
comes some year when graduation
ruins the teatn of the following
year. This was just our case. We
started out with two men who had
played on the team one year, two
who had played two years, and only
one who had played three years.
Even these men had not been regulars all their respective years of

playing. Later several more men
came out who had been subs. About
these men a team had to be built.
As our season started so late we had
to go ahead and play games before
the new and inexperienced men had
been fully drilled. Besides football
has to be born in —a player or else
learned, by experience. Unfortunately, knowledge of football did
not seem to have been born in many
of our crew.
But one of the ways in which we
were benefited was the opportunity
given the undergraduates to learn
at first hand. In a year or two the
team will be a wonder. I only hope
that this season will not influence
the future manager towards easing
up the schedule. I believe there is
no necessity for such action.
Also, I want to thank all the students for the way in which they
have backed us up this fall and particularly all who came out to practice and gave us the largest squad
that there ever has been there.
Thanking you, I am
Very sincerely,
GEORGE M. GILLET, JR.

Co-eds' Cozy Corner

LUNCH AND DINING ROOMS IN BALTIMORE

He's a Bee.

To the Editor of the Co-Ed's Column:
I was very much amused at the
letters in the Co-eds' Column last
week. The•first letter was evidently
written by a fellow, not by a girl,
whether the second one was written
by a fair co-ed, or not. The writer
of the first letter is evidently a
freshman, or, if an upperclassman,
one who knows nothing about girls.
•Probably, he has made a specialty of
old maids; for in his letter he has
the supposed girl say that she wants
to walk up and down the halls arm
in arm with the fellows. Everybody knows that it is the old maid
not the fair maiden who is forced
to make such unblushing suggestions. They are forced like Diogenes ever to be on the look-out for
honest men. The young ,ladies
don't have to. Flowers don't have
to go in search of bees.
I wish to acknowledge from the
very start that I am a bee in search
of f- lowers, and will not pretend I
am a flower in search of bees. What
I am interested in is how to induce
flowers to turn their heads my way.
There was a fine suggestion in Life
the other day, which had been made
by a professor in the University of
Pennsylvania. He said that college students should be encouraged
to write love letters to help them in
their English literature courses. He
claimed that just as birds learn to
sing exquisitely from the practice
they have gotten in singing to their
mates, so college students would
learn to write beautifully if they
were encouraged to write to their
sweethearts. When I had read this I
threw down the Life on the Y. M.
C. A. table at which I had been
reading and went rushing up to Dr.
Greene's room to tell him that I
would be willing to write a love
letter to any girl he might select, if
he would excuse me from the lesson in the Prologue, which he had
assigned for Monday. But when
half way up the stairs, I recollected
that the blooming Pennsylvania professor had said that the letter should
be supervised before being sent to
their destination. I was willing to
let him select the girl I was to write
to, as I felt sure he must know a lot
of lovely ones, but I didn't know if
I would care to have him go oyer
the letters I had written. He might
make me put some Chaucer in them.
But, then, I thought, parts of Chaucer are darn good stuff to put in a
love letter. The arguments in favor
of going to Dr. Greene, and those
for not going being equally balanced,
I decided to write to you to ask \ 11
what I should do.
Anxiously awaiting a reply, I reA BOLD SOPHOMORE.

Sporting Editor The Evening. Sun:
Dear Sir—An article appearing in The
Evening Sun of Monday, November 25,
relating to football affairs at Hopkins,
is full of errors injurious to the institution and to individuals, and we ask
the courtesy of a place on your page for
this letter, signed by all the men especially interested in the article.

The- following categorical denials of
statements or intimations in said article
are made without fear of contradiction:
In headlines and in the body of the
story an assertion appears that the "H"
will not be,given to the players this
year, Bridgenan and La Motte especially being. mentioned. The letters are
awarded by the General Athletic Association, which has not yet met for this
purpose. There has been no movement
to prevent the usual awarding of the
"H"s, and certainly no reason for stating that they will not be awarded;- nor
did Mr. Raleigh, at any time, so state
to any member of the team.
Coach Harlan is represented as being
ready to "throw up the sponge" on many
occasions. This is untrue, and is a gross
injustice to the loyalty and sportsmanship of a coach who has been formally
notified that his work is highly satisfactory.
The entire description of the alleged
action of G. Pitts Raleigh is false, both
as to time, place and substance of his
supposed interviews with players.
The intimation that fraternity rivalries
are responsible for the "smash-up of the
team," not only has no foundation in
fact, but lacks even the appearance of
truth. As evidence of this, Raleigh,
Bridgeman and La Motte, represented as
being at odds, are all members of the
same fraternity.
The statement that funds for equipment were lacking, and that Coach Harlan's requests for apparatus were "turned
down cold," are totally untrue. .
The, utterly inaccurate nature of the.
article is seen in the attempt to fasten
criticism for the playing schedule on
Harry Burgan. Mr. Burgan had absolutely no connection with the football
management until many months after
the schedule was fixed.
,The article concludes with the intimation that while bad luck has played some
part in the defeats of the team, that dissensions, mismanagements and petty politics are really at fault. We do not
care to hide behind "hard luck." There
are a number of definite causes why
games were lost, chief of which is the
scarcity and inexperience of'football material. But losing games does not necessarily mean a totally disastrous season.
. One of the best achievements of the
year has been the solidarity and faithfulness of the football squad as a whole,
and the hearty support of the student
body as evidenced upon such occasions
as the St. John's game.
We trust that your usual fairminded
attitude toward Hopkins athletics will
secure this' letter a prominent place in
your columns.
HORACE BURROUGHS,
HARVEY B. STONE,
Alumni Advisors of Football Team.
E. H. W. HARLAN, Coach,
